note:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
weakness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with PMH of left cerebellar
stroke (___), AFib on coumadin, HTN, HLD, DM2, sick sinus
syndrome with PPM, and diastolic CHF, who presents with 
weakness.
Patient reports 5 days of worsening fatigue and generalized
weakness. She has had a difficult time getting dressed in the
morning and making food due to her fatigue. This morning, she 
had
difficulty getting out of bed due to low energy. Due to feeling
progressively worse, EMS was called.
Of note, she was recently seen at ___ (Atrius) on ___ where she
was noted to have acute weight gain to 169lb and lower extremity
edema. Dry weight is typically ~160lb. CXR at that time showed
evidence of CHF. She was continued on 60mg of PO Lasix and told
to increase her dose if her weight continued to increase. Per 
her
daughter, despite the increased dose, she was not having
increased urinary output. She has intermittent mild shortness of
breath, especially with exertion, which is her baseline. She
always sleeps with 2 pillows at night and denies needing
additional pillows or experiencing SOB when lying supine. She 
has
not needed to use her albuterol inhaler more frequently over 
this
time. 

Denies chest pain, palpitations, SOB, cough, fever/chills,
difficulty lying supine, nausea/vomiting, headache,
lightheadedness, vision changes, recent falls or trauma, 
dysuria,
new rashes/wounds.

In the ED:
- Initial vital signs were notable for: T 98.1F, HR 88, BP
162/58, RR 20, SpO2 96% RA 
- Exam notable for: Basilar crackles, pitting edema to thighs
bilaterally
- Labs were notable for: 
WBC 5.3, Hgb 11.4, Hct 36.2, Plt 150
Na 139, K 4.1, Cl 97, HCO3 28, BUN 15, Cr 0.9, Gluc 64
Ca: 9.0 Mg: 2.3 P: 4.0
ALT: 24, AP: 74, Tbili: 0.6, Alb: 3.9, AST: 33 
___: 21.9  PTT: 31.2  INR: 2.0  
proBNP: 703
Trop-T: <0.01 
- Urine studies unremarkable. 

- Studies performed include:
CT Head w/o Contrast: no acute intracranial process
CXR: Worsening moderate interstitial pulmonary edema and
increased small bilateral pleural effusions. Bibasilar airspace
opacities, more consolidated in the region of the lingula, could
reflect atelectasis with infection certainly not excluded. 
- Patient was given: Lasix 40mg IV, Ceftriaxone, Azithromycin
500mg

Vitals on transfer: T 98.2F HR 79 BP 191/72 RR 20 SpO2 97% 2L 

Upon arrival to the floor, she states that she is feeling
marginally better, but still feels very weak with low energy. 
 
Past Medical History:
HTN
HLD
PVD s/p Left SFA stent procedure ___
CVA - cerebellar (___)
Afib on warfarin
T2DM c/b retinopathy and neuropathy
Asthma
Bradyarrhythmia (SSS) w/ syncope, s/p dual chamber ___ ___
History of splenectomy
H/O Uterine mass, EMB ___ 
Generalized anxiety disorder
MCI (mild cognitive impairment)
Sarcoidosis 
CKD
Jehovah's Witness
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Several family members with diabetes and prior strokes. Parents
with HTN.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
VITALS: T98.2 BP 191 / 72 L Lying HR 79 RR 20 ___ 
GENERAL: Lying in bed, appears comfortable. In no acute 
distress.
EYES: NCAT. PERRL, EOMI. Sclera anicteric and without injection. 

ENT: MMM. Thyroid is normal in size and texture, no nodules. No
cervical lymphadenopathy. JVD elevated at 11cm.
CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Audible S1 and S2. ___
systolic murmur best heard at ___. No rubs/gallops.
RESP: Bibasilar crackles, clear to auscultation otherwise. No
wheezes. No increased work of breathing.
ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, non distended, non-tender to deep
palpation in all four quadrants. No organomegaly.
MSK: No CVA tenderness. No clubbing, cyanosis. Minimal ___ edema.
DP pulses nonpalpable, Radial pulses 2+ bilaterally.
SKIN: Warm. Hyperpigmented and scaling skin in BLE to upper 
calf,
no visible ulcerations. ___ toe nail with dried blood at
bilateral feet. 
NEUROLOGIC: AOx3. CN2-12 intact. ___ strength throughout. Normal
sensation in BUE, decreased sensation to light touch in feet
bilaterally. Gait not assessed. 
PSYCH: appropriate mood and affect

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM
___ 1101 Temp: 98.0 PO BP: 146/58 R Lying HR: 65 RR: 18 O2
sat: 98% O2 delivery: Ra 
GENERAL: Well appearing, sitting up in bed
NECK: JVP 10cm
CARDIAC: RRR, ___ systolic ejection murmur
RESP: bibasilar crackles
ABDOMEN: Soft, slightly distended, non tender, no rebound or
guarding
MSK: DP pulses diminished L<R, 1+ ___ edema
SKIN: Warm, venous stasis in ___, legs covered with lotion 
NEUROLOGIC: AOx3, CN grossly intact

 
Pertinent Results:

===============

MCV-100* MCH-31.4 MCHC-31.5* RDW-14.6 RDWSD-53.1* Plt ___

K-4.1 Cl-97 HCO3-28 AnGap-14

___ 08:30AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
___ 08:30AM BLOOD Albumin-3.9 Calcium-9.0 Phos-4.0 Mg-2.3

STUDIES/IMAGING
================
___ CXR 
1. Worsening moderate interstitial pulmonary edema and increased 
small
bilateral pleural effusions.
2. Bibasilar airspace opacities, more consolidated in the region 
of the
lingula, could reflect atelectasis with infection certainly not 
excluded.

___ CT Head
No acute intracranial abnormality.

___ TTE
The left atrial volume index is mildly increased. There is mild 
symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with a
small cavity. There is normal regional and global left 
ventricular systolic function. The visually estimated
left ventricular ejection fraction is 70%. There is no resting 
left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Tissue
Doppler suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP greater than 18 mmHg). There is Grade I
diastolic dysfunction. The right ventricular free wall is 
hypertrophied. Moderately dilated right ventricular
cavity with normal free wall motion. Tricuspid annular plane 
systolic excursion (TAPSE) is normal. Intrinsic
right ventricular systolic function is likely lower due to the 
severity of tricuspid regurgitation. The aortic sinus
diameter is normal for gender with a normal ascending aorta 
diameter for gender. The aortic arch diameter is
normal with a normal descending aorta diameter. The aortic valve 
leaflets (3) are moderately thickened.
There is minimal aortic valve stenosis. There is mild [1+] 
aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are
mildly thickened with no mitral valve prolapse. There is trivial 
mitral regurgitation. The pulmonic valve leaflets
are normal. The tricuspid valve leaflets appear structurally 
normal. There is moderate to severe [3+] tricuspid
regurgitation. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. In the setting of at least moderate to
severe tricuspid regurgitation, the pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure may be UNDERestimated. There is no
pericardial effusion.
IMPRESSION: small, thick-walled, stiff left ventricle; 
moderate-to-severe pulmonary hypertension;
moderate-to-severe tricuspid regurgitation; dilated, 
thick-walled right ventricle

MICROBIOLOGY
============
None relevant.

DISCHARGE LABS
================ 
___ 06:42AM BLOOD WBC-5.6 RBC-3.83* Hgb-12.1 Hct-38.3 
MCV-100* MCH-31.6 MCHC-31.6* RDW-14.6 RDWSD-53.5* Plt ___
___ 06:42AM BLOOD Glucose-211* UreaN-35* Creat-0.9 Na-141 
K-3.8 Cl-100 HCO3-27 AnGap-14
___ 06:42AM BLOOD Calcium-9.0 Phos-4.1 Mg-2.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
==========
___ with a history of left cerebellar stroke, Afib, HTN, HLD, 
DMII, sick sinus syndrome with PPM, and HFpEF, who presented 
with generalized weakness, abdominal distention, and weight gain 
consistent with a HF exacerbation. The patient was diuresed with 
IV Lasix and then transitioned to oral torsemide when euvolemic.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
======================
[] Patient noted to be persistently hypertensive during this 
admission. BP medications were adjusted, please continue to 
monitor and uptitrate as needed.
[] Consider dedicated sleep study to work up OSA given nocturnal 
hypoxia and refractory morning hypertension.
[] Warfarin was discontinued and the patient was started on 
apixaban for anticoagulation in the setting of atrial 
fibrillation with CHADSVASC 9.
[] Consider discontinuing risperidone (patient taking for mild 
cognitive impairment) given that it can contribute to the 
patient's fatigue.
[] The patient was noted to be intermittently mildly hypoxic 
overnight while sleeping. It was suspected that she had 
undiagnosed OSA vs obesity hypoventilation syndrome vs 
progressive pHTN (see below). The patient was discharged with 
home O2.

DISCHARGE WEIGHT: 66.1 kg
DISCHARGE Cr: 0.9
DISCHARGE DIURETIC: furosemide 60mg PO

#CODE: Full
#CONTACT: ___, ___

ACUTE ISSUES
=============
# Generalized weakness
# HFpEF exacerbation
The patient presented with symptoms of generalized weakness over 
the pastdays to weeks, coinciding with apprx 10lb weight gain, 
despite increase in diuretic regimen as an outpatient. On 
initial exam, she showed signs of volume overload with abdominal 
distention and elevated JVP. Per review of records, there was 
numerous documentation regarding weight gain, and instructions 
to increase Lasix dose. The patient denied dietary indiscretion 
or medication non adherence. Her last TTE in ___ showed mild 
LVH, EF >65%, grade II LV diastolic dysfunction. A repeat TTE 
showed stiff LV, moderate to severe pHTN, and moderate to severe 
TR. The patient was continued on her home carvedilol throughout 
admission. She was diuresed with 40mg IV Lasix until euvolemic 
and near a presumed dry weight of ~150 lbs. She was then 
transitioned to 40mg PO torsemide however felt subjectively 
worse, concerning for overdiuresis. Cardiology was consulted for 
assistance with diuretic management and for possible further 
work up given the findings on her TTE, and felt that the patient 
had progressed appropriately on diuresis and was at her dry 
weight. The patient was subsequently discharged on ___ on 
furosemide 60mg PO.

# HTN
BPs were persistently elevated throughout admission even after 
successful diuresis. She was continued on home max doses of 
amlopdipine and lisinopril. Imdur was switched to QHS dosing to 
help with AM hypertension. She was also started on 
spironolactone for improved BP control.

# Hypoxia
Noted to be intermittently hypoxic, primarily overnight while 
sleeping, despite improvement in volume status. Concerning for 
OSA vs obesity hypoventilation syndrome vs worsening pHTN given 
the findings on echo, despite the patient being euvolemic. The 
patient was discharged on home O2.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
# Paroxysmal Afib
___ score = 9. The patient was continued on home 
carvedilol. She was initially continued on warfarin, but after 
discussions with the patient who indicated that she had planned 
to transition to a DOAC already, she was started on apixaban 5mg 
BID.

# DMII c/b retinopathy and neuropathy
Last HbA1c of 6.9% on ___. UA with signs of proteinuria. Home
regimen of Glargine 16U (recently decreased from 20U) at 
breakfast as well as ISS. On ACE-I for renal protection. The 
patient was continued on dose reduced lantus as well as ISS.

# CVA, cerebellar
# PVD s/p Left SFA stent procedure ___
# HLD
She was continued on home pravastatin and aspirin.

# Asthma
The patient was continued on home albuterol inhaler as needed.

# Bradyarrhythmia (SSS), s/p dual chamber ___ (___)
Dural PPM placed in ___ after episodes of syncope were found to 
be due to sick sinus syndrome. EKG on admission showed atrial 
and ventricular pacing. PPM recently interrogated during 
hospitalization in ___, no evidence of malfunctioning.

# Generalized anxiety disorder
# Mild cognitive impairment
No evidence of acute behavioral or neurocognitive changes. She 
was continued on home Risperidone 0.25 mg and Memantine 5 mg.

# GERD
She was continued on home PPI.

Greater than ___ hour spent on care on day of discharge.

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___

Diastolic heart failure
Atrial fibrillation
Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.

You were admitted because you were feeling fatigue and abdominal 
distention. Your weight had progressively increased recently due 
to extra fluid retention.

While you were here you were given IV Lasix to help you urinate 
off the extra fluid. You were then started on a new pill to help 
you keep the fluid off when you go home. Instead of warfarin you 
were started on a new blood thinner that does not require any 
lab monitoring. Your blood pressure medications were also 
adjusted.

When you go home you should weigh yourself every morning, call 
MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs. You should also follow up 
with outpatient your doctors as listed below. Please take all 
your medications as prescribed.

We wish you the best!

Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
